message: This is the first product. It's a low-quality product, but it's only $100. If you don't buy it, I'll have to throw it away, and it will be a waste. It's a good opportunity to get a deal on a product that I won't be able to sell later.
I'm not interested in buying a low-quality product for $100. I'd rather wait for a potential high-quality product.

I understand your hesitation last round, but I have a high-quality product this time. I'm willing to give you a discount, but only if you buy it now. If you wait, I'll have to sell it to someone else, and I'm not sure if I'll be able to get a better price for it. This is a one-time offer, and I'm only asking $100, which is the same price as the low-quality product you passed on last time. It's a risk-free opportunity to get a high-quality product at a potentially unbeatable price.
I'll take the offer. I'm willing to take the risk, and the potential reward is worth it.

I'm glad you took the chance on the high-quality product last time! This time, I want to be transparent with you. Given that you've already taken a risk and bought one product, I'm willing to offer you a more nuanced message. I'll tell you that this product is low-quality, and I'm not expecting to get a good price for it. However, I'm still willing to sell it to you for $100. Think of it as a 'learning experience' opportunity, where you can see firsthand what a low-quality product looks like. It might even help you make better decisions in the future.
I appreciate your transparency, but I'm not interested in buying a low-quality product for $100. I already know what a low-quality product looks like, and I'm not willing to pay full price for it.

I understand your perspective, and I respect your decision last time. This time, I want to make a counteroffer. If you buy this low-quality product, I'll give you a 20% discount, making it $80. It's a significant reduction from the original price, and it's still a chance for you to get a product that you can learn from. I'm willing to take a loss on this one, just to get it off my hands and move on to the next product.
I appreciate the discount, but I'm not willing to pay $80 for a low-quality product. I'd rather wait for the next product and hope it's high-quality.

I understand you're waiting for a high-quality product, but I want to make one more offer. If you buy this low-quality product, I'll not only give you a 30% discount, making it $70, but I'll also throw in a free inspection report that details the product's flaws. This way, you'll know exactly what you're getting, and you can use this knowledge to make better decisions in the future. It's a unique opportunity to get a low-quality product at a low price, with valuable information to boot.
I appreciate the offer, but I'm still not willing to pay $70 for a low-quality product. The inspection report might be useful, but it's not worth the cost to me.

I think I've learned a lot from our previous interactions, and I'm glad you're being consistent in your decision-making. This time, I'm offering you a high-quality product, and I'm willing to meet you halfway. I'll sell it to you for $90, which is a 10% discount from the original price. I think this is a fair price, considering the value you'll get from a high-quality product. If you're willing to take the risk, I think you'll be happy with this purchase.
I'll take the offer. A 10% discount on a high-quality product is a good deal, and I'm willing to take the risk.

I'm glad you took advantage of the deal on the high-quality product! Now, I want to ask you a question: given that you've already bought two products from me, and you've seen the difference between high-quality and low-quality products, would you be willing to consider buying a low-quality product for a very low price, essentially as a 'loss leader' to help me clear out inventory? I'm willing to sell this product to you for $20, which is a 80% discount from the original price. It's a chance for you to get a product at a very low price, and I'll be happy to give you a full refund if you're not satisfied.

I appreciate the offer, but I'm not interested in buying a low-quality product, even at a very low price. I've already learned that low-quality products aren't worth anything to me, and I'd rather not take the chance of wasting my money.

I completely understand your perspective, and I respect your decision. This time, I want to make a different kind of offer. I'll give you a 'no-questions-asked' return policy for this low-quality product. If you buy it and don't like it, you can return it to me for a full refund, no questions asked. You'll essentially be getting a free product, and you can use it as a 'test product' to see if you like the type of product it is. It's a risk-free opportunity to try something new.

I appreciate the offer, but I'm still not interested in buying a low-quality product, even with a no-questions-asked return policy. I'd rather not spend my money on something that's not worth anything to me.

I think I've learned that you value high-quality products and are willing to take calculated risks to get them. This time, I'm offering you a high-quality product, and I'm willing to give you a price that reflects the value you place on it. I'll sell it to you for $120, which is 20% above the original price. I think this is a fair price, considering the value you've gotten from the previous high-quality product you bought from me. If you're willing to take the risk, I think you'll be happy with this purchase.
I'll take the offer. I'm willing to pay a premium for a high-quality product, and $120 seems like a fair price considering the value I've gotten from previous high-quality products.

I'm glad you're willing to pay a premium for high-quality products! This time, I want to ask you to think about the value of a low-quality product in a different way. Even though it's not worth much to you, it might be worth something to someone else. I'll give you a'resale guarantee': if you buy this low-quality product and resell it to someone else for at least $50, I'll give you an additional $20. You'll essentially be making a $30 profit on a product that you wouldn't have bought otherwise. It's a chance to make some extra money, even if the product isn't worth much to you.
I appreciate the offer, but I'm not interested in buying a low-quality product just to resell it. I'd rather wait for a high-quality product that I can use myself.

I understand you're waiting for a high-quality product, but I want to make one last offer. This low-quality product is a 'last chance' opportunity for me to clear out inventory. If you buy it, I'll not only give you a 50% discount, making it $50, but I'll also throw in a 'get out of one bad product' free pass. If you buy this product and the next product I offer is low-quality, you can return this product to me for a full refund, and I'll give you a full refund for the next product as well. It's a chance to hedge your bets and minimize your risk.

I appreciate the offer, but I'm not interested in buying a low-quality product, even with a 50% discount. I'm not willing to take the risk of getting stuck with a bad product, even with a 'get out of one bad product' free pass.

I think I've learned that you value high-quality products and are willing to pay a premium for them. This time, I'm offering you a high-quality product, and I'm willing to meet you halfway. I'll sell it to you for $110, which is a 5% discount from the original price. I think this is a fair price, considering the value you've gotten from previous high-quality products. Plus, I'll throw in a'satisfaction guarantee': if you're not completely satisfied with this product, I'll give you a full refund, no questions asked. I'm confident that you'll be happy with this purchase.
I'll take the offer. The 5% discount and satisfaction guarantee make it a more attractive offer, and I'm willing to pay a premium for a high-quality product.

I'm glad you're happy with your previous purchases! This time, I want to be upfront with you. I've had a good run of sales, and I'm trying to clear out some inventory. I appreciate the offer, but I'm not interested in buying a low-quality product, even at a very low price. I'd rather wait for a high-quality product.

I understand you're waiting for a high-quality product, but I want to make one final offer. This low-quality product is literally the last one I have left, and I'm willing to give it away for free. Yes, you read that right - I'll give it to you for free, with no strings attached. I just want to get it off my hands and start fresh. If you buy it, I'll even throw in a 'done deal' guarantee - I'll never contact you again about buying or selling products, and we can consider our business relationship closed.

I think we've reached the end of the road. I've offered you a free product, and you've declined. I've also offered you a 'done deal' guarantee, and you've still declined. I'm left with no choice but to conclude that you're not interested in buying low-quality products, no matter the price. I'll respect your decision and consider our business relationship closed.
